results.description:
HELLOOOOO BROOKLYN! Our last Amazing Scavenger Hunt Meetup in BK was a big hit so we're doing it again! 

This is an INDOOR hunt and includes admission to the Brooklyn Museum. You will receive a series of clues and perform mental and physical (nothing too strenuous) challenges along the way. 

It is a great way to connect with friends or meet new ones. You can sign up as a team (2-4 members) or as an individual and we will partner you with a team. Each member of the winning team receives a gift package.

GET TICKETS HERE - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Nov-21-2015_at_1230PM

What to expect:  

• Admission to the Brooklyn Museum

• A fun day with with new friends 

• Mental and physical challenges

• A memorable adventure with photos

• A story to tell

PREPAY ONLY EVENT (No tickets sold at door)  

*GET TICKETS AT THIS LINK ($30) - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Nov-21-2015_at_1230PM

*We only have a limited # of tix available. Ticket price will go up as event gets closer so get yours ASAP.

Who can attend? All are welcome. This is not an age/ethnic/gender specific event. 

What should I wear? Dress for the elements. Be prepared for a day of walking.  Dress comfortable – Most teams wear sneakers.

What should I bring? A fun attitude, a smart phone if you have (fully charged). The hunt is run through an app called ScanQuest.  You can download that before you come.

Where do we go? There’s no set course. Find your own way. It’s a ‘choose your own adventure hunt. 

What if it rains? No problem, the scavenger hunt is all indoors.

How many people will be attending? This is a multi-Meetup event and we have over 20 groups co-organizing it. We expect up to 40 members to attend.

Where do I get a ticket? You must prepay here to attend. Tickets will not be sold at the door. We expect this event to sell out so please get your tickets ASAP here - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Nov-21-2015_at_1230PM

results.description:
Due to the success of the past Nordic Walks in Central Park and the sold-out 11:00 am meet up on Saturday - we have added this new time slot. This class is for those that have had either previous Nordic walking experience, received instruction from our past classes or simply want a more challenging cardio workout.

The basics of Nordic Walking will be applied but additional interval training techniques will be introduced to increase heart rate and intensity of the walk.

Remember to leave your bags at home and wear either a belt bag or backpack.  Hydrate before the walk - but remember there are no bathroom stops. Temperature should be in the low 50's, wear layers.

Come 10 minutes early so that we can fix you up with the poles and wireless music audio.  We supply the poles  - just bring earphones.  There is a 10 min warmup/instruction and approximate 50 min walk.   We start at west 72nd st - walk up to and around the reservoir and back to 72nd st.  Total miles 2.75.

Click on www.HYVAnordicwalking.com for all the details....

Bill and Sonja
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us at the  west 72nd St entrance to Central Park - we're the  guys with the poles!
results.name: Advanced Nordic Walk

group.name: Central Park  Nordic Walking Fitness Class

results.description:
Many members have been asking for our Saturday Figure Drawing Session.

Join us for three hours of figure drawing in the heart of The Flatiron District.

This session is open to sketchers of all levels.


What makes our sessions different? 

• We work in a large, clean, well-lit space. 

• Sketchers can concentrate because our room is quiet while the model is posing.

• (Latecomers can be seated at a break.) 

• Every hour we take a break to look each others drawings (if you choose to put yours out.) This is a nonjudgmental and very valuable part of the session. 

• This is a three hour drawing session to work from a live (nude) model.   

• We start with 5 minute poses and work up to 20 minute poses by the end of the session. We take a 5 minute break every 20 minutes. 

• There are seats for everyone tables and several light weight easels.  

• Access to a sink is available for watercolor artist.

• Bring your own materials (no oil or acrylic paint and no sprays please.)

Our amazing space!

As always if you have any questions please feel free to email me. I look forward to seeing you there. 

Simon
results.how_to_find_us: We meet in Studio #505
results.name: Saturday - Live Model Drawing - Flatiron District

results.description:
In the spirit of Thanksgiving, bring in a book (or just the title of a book) that's changed your life in some way. It could be a book that you read through the night because it was just that good, or one that made you feel more powerful. Whatever book comes to mind, ask yourself why.

We'll discuss the books, authors and impacts, and do a writing prompt around the gift we got from the book. 

A second writing prompt: What message do you want your writing to give to readers? What gift do you want readers to walk away with from your finished book/project?

The last hour is devoted to sharing and commenting on projects. We'll limit time if we have a lot of readers.

Housekeeping note: Starting with the December Meetup, we're changing to once a month, 2 hours. The meetup will now be on the 3rd Saturday of every month from 2 to 4 p.m.

Feel free to connect amongst yourselves to have informal writing circles to help each other get work done and hammer out rough patches. 

See you Saturday!
results.how_to_find_us: We'll have some chairs and tables pulled together and a small sign. Look for people gathered with laptops and notebooks, paper and pens.
results.name: Writing, discussion and projects: What Book Are You Most Thankful For?

results.description:
Please make sure you read & understand all of the details below.

Hello everyone. I want to have us get together & have a good time while getting to know others at my place. Any more details for this event will be posted ASAP but I wanted to get something up for the time being. At this time this is what I'm shooting for this year:

Turkey & Ham

Sides:
Honey Cornbread
Collar Greens
Homemade Cranberry Raisin Sauce
Baked Beans
Sweet Potato Yams
a variation of Mac & Cheese
Red Bliss Potato Salad...

Dessert:
Assorted Cookies
Some type of dessert

Drinks: Some form of Vodka, Bacardi Rum, Maker's Mark, Some type of Tequila, Mixers, Juices, Sodas, Coffee & Teas

All I ask is for you to cover for the food & drink cost (at least $10) but look at it this way, it was a big success last year so I'm trying to make it a little bigger this year. If you have any questions, feel free to contact me at anytime.

Being as this event is a long event, you don't need to stay for the whole event. Mostly it's just you coming here, hang, eat & socialize with other people. Feel free to come & go as you please.

I do ask for particular things:

(1) Since I will be providing food & drinks at this event, I ask for at least $10.00 to cover the cost.

(2) Prepare to travel accordingly to & from my place as I live in Queens now. Go to maps on Google & Yahoo to get directions. You can also go to your IPhone or your GPS on your android if you have one.

(3) Once you arrive I ask that you respect the neighbors place of residence & not do anything that would bring unwanted attention.

Directions:

[A] If traveling on the (7) train & walking:

Take the train to the stop of 103rd Street-Corona Park. Walk downstairs to the street & walk to 104th Street (there is a post office on the corner). Turn Right on that street & you will walk a few blocks (in the same direction of traffic). You will run into Corona Avenue. Turn Left & walk on that road until you hit 108th Street. Turn Right & walk to 53rd Avenue. Turn Right & my building is the 1st one on the right side with the balconies.

[B] If traveling on the (7) Train & Q23 Bus:

Take the train to the stop of 103rd Street-Corona Park. Walk downstairs to the street & walk to 104th Street. Turn Left & walk a half-block until you see the Q23 Bus Stop. Take the bus & stay on it until you get to the stop of 108th Street & 53rd Avenue. Get off. Turn & walk to 53rd Street. My building is the 1st one on the right side with the balconies.

[C] If traveling on the (E)(F)(M)(R) train & Q58 Bus:

Take one of these trains to 71st Avenue-Forest Hills in Queens. get out & transfer to a Q58 Bus. Ride that bus (about 15 minutes) until you get to the stop of 108th Street & Martense Avenue. Get off & Walk to 53rd Avenue. Cross the street & look for a set of buildings with balconies. I'm in the one on the right side (also look for the number on the door).

I will be combining this with multiple groups so if you rsvp, do it on only one list (it makes things easier for guest list purpose).

Enjoy your day today & I'll see you in November.
results.name: Thanksgiving Grindhouse!

results.description:
Our next meetup will focus on: Science.

If you'd like to do some prior reading/viewing for this topic, check out the following (optional) resources:

The Experimenter - a new film in theaters right now chronicling the life and (in)famous experiments of Stanley Milgram, whose name has cropped up at past Dialectic meetups more than a few times.


The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy also has a number of interesting articles addressing science ("Science and Pseudo-Science," "Models in Science," "Religion and Science" etc.).

The meetup runs as follows:


1) The moderator selects one subject for discussion and a date for the meeting. Subjects can be as ephemeral as "love," "god," and "purpose," or as grounded as "politics," "environmentalism," and "family."

2) At the meetup, people are encouraged to propose a question related to the subject. The moderator will collect all of the questions in a list. Questions may also be proposed ahead of time online on the event page.

3) The group will then vote on the questions. In the first round of voting, each individual may vote for as many questions as they like. The top three will then go to a second round, where each individual may vote just once.

4) The question with the most votes is then discussed. Often, the discussion starts with a narrowing of the question, as it can be challenging to devise a question that can possibly be answered by a small group in just a couple of hours' discussion.

Finally, please consider making a small donation to help the moderator cover subscription costs.

The Winter Garden is a spectacular 3-story barrel-vaulted glass atrium, offering panoramic views of the World Trade Center and Lower Manhattan at one end, and showcasing a majestic bay window with magnificent views of the Hudson River on the other. results.description:
City of Glass by Paul Karasik,David Mazzucchelli,Art Spiegelman(Introduction),Paul Auster

Quinn writes mysteries. The Washington Post has described him as a “post-existentialist private eye.” An unknown voice on the telephone is now begging for his help, drawing him into a world and a mystery far stranger than any he ever created in print.

Adapted by Paul Karasik and David Mazzucchelli, with graphics by David Mazzucchelli, Paul Auster’s groundbreaking, Edgar Award-nominated masterwork has been astonishingly transformed into a new visual language.

Fun Home: A Family Tragicomic by Alison Bechdel

In this graphic memoir, Alison Bechdel charts her fraught relationship with her late father.

Distant and exacting, Bruce Bechdel was an English teacher and director of the town funeral home, which Alison and her family referred to as the Fun Home. It was not until college that Alison, who had recently come out as a lesbian, discovered that her father was also gay. A few weeks after this revelation, he was dead, leaving a legacy of mystery for his daughter to resolve.

The final vote after adding the votes taken at the September meeting to the poll votes is--

City of Glass--7

Fun Home--4

Daytrippers--2

The Filth--2

Seconds--0
results.name: November --  City of Glass / Fun Home: A Family Tragicomic

results.description:
Please make sure you read & understand all of the details below.

Hello everyone. I want to have us get together & have a good time while getting to know others at my place. Any more details for this event will be posted ASAP but I wanted to get something up for the time being. At this time this is what I'm shooting for this year:

Turkey & Ham

Sides:
Honey Cornbread
Collar Greens
Homemade Cranberry Raisin Sauce
Baked Beans
Sweet Potato Yams
Mac & Cheese
Potato Salad...

Dessert:
Assorted Cookies
Some type of dessert

Drinks: Some form of Vodka, Bacardi Rum, Maker's Mark, Some type of Tequila, Mixers, Juices, Sodas, Coffee & Teas

Being as this event is a long event, you don't need to stay for the whole event. Mostly it's just you coming here, hang, eat & socialize with other people. Feel free to come & go as you please.

I do ask for particular things:

(1) Since I will be providing food & drinks at this event, I ask for at least $10.00 to cover the cost.

(2) Prepare to travel accordingly to & from my place as I live in Queens now. Go to maps on Google & Yahoo to get directions. You can also go to your IPhone or your GPS on your android if you have one.

(3) Once you arrive I ask that you respect the neighbors place of residence & not do anything that would bring unwanted attention.

Directions:

[A] If traveling on the (7) train & walking:

Take the train to the stop of 103rd Street-Corona Park. Walk downstairs to the street & walk to 104th Street (there is a post office on the corner). Turn Right on that street & you will walk a few blocks (in the same direction of traffic). You will run into Corona Avenue. Turn Left & walk on that road until you hit 108th Street. Turn Right & walk to 53rd Avenue. Turn Right & my building is the 1st one on the right side with the balconies.

[B] If traveling on the (7) Train & Q23 Bus:

Take the train to the stop of 103rd Street-Corona Park. Walk downstairs to the street & walk to 104th Street. Turn Left & walk a half-block until you see the Q23 Bus Stop. Take the bus & stay on it until you get to the stop of 108th Street & 53rd Avenue. Get off. Turn & walk to 53rd Street. My building is the 1st one on the right side with the balconies.

[C] If traveling on the (E)(F)(M)(R) train & Q58 Bus:

Take one of these trains to 71st Avenue-Forest Hills in Queens. get out & transfer to a Q58 Bus. Ride that bus (about 15 minutes) until you get to the stop of 108th Street & Martense Avenue. Get off & Walk to 53rd Avenue. Cross the street & look for a set of buildings with balconies. I'm in the one on the right side (also look for the number on the door).

I will be combining this with multiple groups so if you rsvp, do it on only one list (it makes things easier for guest list purposes) 

 Enjoy your day today & I'll see you in November

results.description:
Many members have specifically requesting reading books written by women authors. So how about a book written not by just any woman, but by the first American woman to be awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature?

Pearl S. Buck was the daughter of Christian missionaries in China. She spent the majority of her first 40 years of life in China--her first language was Chinese and even as an adult she thought in Chinese and translated these thoughts into English when she began writing and publishing stories. Pearl was largely responsible for bringing an understanding of Chinese culture to America and was a huge advocate of women and minority rights and the adoption of Asian children by American families. 

The Good Earth was published in 1931 and awarded the Pulitzer Prize for the Novel in 1932. The best-selling novel in the United States in both 1931 and 1932 was an influential factor in Buck's winning the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1938. The novel, which dramatizes family life in a Chinese village before World War I, has been a steady favorite ever since. It was included in Life Magazine's list of the 100 outstanding books of 1924–1944. In 2004, the book was returned to the bestseller list when chosen by the television host Oprah Winfrey for Oprah's Book Club. The novel helped prepare Americans of the 1930s to consider Chinese as allies in the coming war with Japan. It has been adapted into both a Broadway play in 1932 and a movie in 1937. 

Even though Buck was white, Chinese readers often comment on how authentic her description of the Chinese experience was. Though she spent the last several decades of her life in America, she was often quoted as saying she had never left China. 

This book is a manageable 350 pages long. After this I will make a point of selecting books no longer than 200 pages so people aren't overwhelmed during the holidays. If the weather holds out we'll meet in Central Park, if not, we'll meet in my apartment in Washington Heights.
results.name: Pearl S. Buck's The Good Earth--Pulitzer Prize and Nobel Prize for Literature

It is important for us as students of spirituality and mysticism to become aware and acquainted with the tremendous resources that are available to us to make our lives more harmonious.


Once we learn to tap these inner resources, living will be an invigorating affair continuing and picking up where we left off in previous life experiences and thereby advancing and expanding the consciousness.

We need to keep foremost in our consciousness certain principles, conditions and laws to gain access to spiritual tools and to arrive at permanent solutions to life's challenges.

Through lectures, participation in meditation, and visualization exercises, we will be given the opportunity to experience the value of discussing these principles in a group setting.

Learn to Salsa New York Style with Yrma Arias at El Taller! This style of Salsa, "On 2", has gained popularity over the last decade in NYC. The classes will focus on the look and feel of the dance - with an emphasis on timing, footwork and partner work. Classes will provide instruction and repetition of the steps ‘Shines’, introduce the importance of the leader/follower connection, and provide practical techniques for the Latin Motion. Particular attention is paid to rhythm and musicality. This is an enjoyable class designed for people of all ages. The most important lesson is to have fun! What to bring: A great attitude and comfortable clothes and shoes that allow you to move!


When you arrive at 215 E. 99th Street, press the El T button on the intercom and we'll buzz you right in!

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

This is a co-ed adult pick-up game 6v6 or 7 v7 depending on attendance. 90 minutes with two 45 minute halves. No slide tackling or rough play. We play with Pugg goals. Pinnies provided.  Shin guards are recommended.


This pick up game is hosted by Coach Moe and is free for those who attended both training sessions with him the same day, $4 for all others.


PLEASE UPDATE YOUR RSVP AT LEAST 2 HOURS BEFORE THE GAME!

• Update your RSVP by 11:30AM

• RSVPs close by 12 NOON

• No shows and those who didn't update their RSVP at least 2 hours before the game will be red carded after the second offense, which means that we have the right to edit your RSVP.

Directions by subway or bus:

2 and 3 trains to Clark St.

A and C trains to High St.


F train to York St.


N and R trains to Court St.


Weather policy:

In case of inclement weather we will send out an email to notify you at least two hours before meeting time.

What to bring:

Please note that Cadman Plaza park is a turf field. Turf shoes are preferred. Please bring water or sports drink. Please bring a ball if you have one.


By RSVP-ing YES you agree to the following:

I certify that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in Williamsburg Soccer Training activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore, I, individually, hereby release and discharge, Williamsburg Soccer Training Organizer and Assistant Organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of Williamsburg Soccer Training programs or activities.

results.description:
Saturday afternoon! 


Delve into the twisted mind of Norman Bates as we analyze Alfred Hitchcock's PSYCHO.

Whether you're a casual movie fan or seasoned cinephile, this workshop is a fun opportunity to learn more about what goes into the craft of moviemaking.

We'll take a look under the cinematic hood and see how the motion picture engine runs by discussing how the following crafts are woven together to create the power of movies:


Screenwriting - Blueprint for a Movie
Acting - Breathing Life into Characters
Production Design - Sets, Costumes, Props
Camera & Lighting - Directing Visual Stories
Editing - Putting the Puzzle Together

Everyone should watch the preselected movie in advance. During the workshop, the group watches various selected scenes from the chosen flick and we dissect and discuss each scene.

The Movie Appreciation Workshop is held in the screening room of the always fun Videology Bar and Cinema in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Drinking and eating during the workshop are encouraged.

Several trivia questions about the selected movie are asked throughout each workshop. The winner gets a FREE drink ticket!

Explore movies you love, learn terminology and gain insight into the creative filmmaking process. Join other cinema enthusiasts for an entertaining and enlightening lecture/ conversation about the magic that is the movies!

For those interested, checkout the screenplay for Psycho, here:     http://www.imsdb.com/scripts/Psycho.html
results.name: Movie Appreciation Workshop:  The Craft Behind Movie Magic in PYSCHO

Come join us at the Codesters office for professional development, food, and networking. During our regular meetups teachers come together to share best practices, increase their knowledge of Python, and create projects in the Codesters platform. 

This month, will be dedicated to planning and preparing your own Hour of Code event for your classroom or school. Hour of Code is an event that occurs during Computer Science Education Week (December 7 - 13, 2015). During this week, schools all over the globe will host events that allow all of their students to try one hour of coding. During the meetup, we will walk-through of the official Codesters Hour of Code site. Partipants will have the opportunity to plan their own Hour of Code event. We will share resources and tips for running an event tailored to your own educational community.

results.description:
Bonjour les Ami(e)s,

Nous allons faire un meetup chez moi le 21 Novembre. Je sais que ça fait un moment, mais nous avons été très occupés.

Je vous suggère d’y aller dans les plats au four, soupes, potages, fromages, etc.

Le dernier meetup à central park était fantastique – on mise sur la qualité et la préparation plutôt que la quantité.

SVP – ne pas ramasser un truc moche 10 minutes avant d’arriver, arriver plutôt avec plus de boisson. En effet il y a généralement trop de nourriture! Merci à nos cuistots habituels.

Je vais commencer avec une limite de 15, elle sera augmentée graduellement. Si vous voulez plaider votre cause avec des plats irrésistibles contactez-moi.

À très bientôt les ami(e)s!

Yan

results.description:
Join us for couple hours of fashion fun!

If you are like me, you have tons of great items in your closets that you've never worn or will never wear again. Instead of throwing them out or leaving them in your closet to take up space, why not trade them? We will be hosting a Swap event on Saturday November 21st. Bring all your fab unwanted clothing (shoes, bags, jewelry, and accessories also) and trade them with fellow fashionistas!

Details:

-Bring 10-25 items in great condition (clean, no holes, stains or buttons missing). Each item will be inspected at the start of the event.

-For every item you bring, you are able to swap 1 for 1. We will be issuing tickets to make sure that the exchange is fair.

-Any item brought is up for grabs, so regardless what you bring, you can swap it for something you like regardless of price range or item (shoes can be swapped for a top, etc.)

-This is a free event however we are collecting donations for God's Love We Deliver (www.glwd.com) and we ask that everyone in attendance make a small donation that day...$5, $10, etc. All proceeds will be donated To God's Love We Deliver to help provide food for people who are too sick to shop or cook on their own. Donation will be collected at the start of the event. Cash only please.

This event is being held by Samantha, the organizer of the meetup group Just Us Girlfriends.


Hope to see you there :)
results.name: Fashion Swap 'Til You Drop/Charity Event

results.description:
Sustainable Flatbush & Sacred Vibes Apothecary host the final FREE community workshop for the season on the use of herbs for health and wellness.

Join Sacred Vibes Apothecary Herbal Apprentices and proud Caribbeans, Myrna and Shamilia for this lively exploration of a rich legacy. We'll share healing stories and create plant medicine in the flowering traditions of the Caribbean amidst music, refreshments and delicacies of the region.

Location: This workshop will be held in Myrna's home on East 18th St near Church Ave in Brooklyn. We will be limiting attendance to 15 people, so please RSVP to the email below to hold your spot! We will reply to your RSVP with the location of the workshop.

To RSVP, or for more information, please email: [masked]

This workshop is FREE, but we always welcome donations to help cover the costs of supplies and refreshments.

Materials: In many of our workshops we spend time making different herbal preparations such as teas, tinctures, oils, and syrups. If you would like to bring some home with you, please bring a clean 2 oz. baby food jar. If you have more than 1 jar, bring some to share!

Accessibility: It is important to us that our workshops are as accessible as possible. Please contact Kate at [masked] if you have any accessibility concerns or needs.
results.name: BUSH MEDICINE: Stories and Plant Allies of the Caribbean

results.description:
Does history repeat itself, and what can we learn from the past in order to avoid making the same mistakes in the future?


All of us are searching for solutions on this journey through life, but how important is looking at the past to understanding our lives today and its effects on those around us?

Join the conversation, share your thoughts and experiences, and let's help one another discover new solutions together.

results.description:
Our typical agenda: - We orient new visitors and then chat a bit, as by sharing what's new or good in our lives. - Then we chant and meditate together, together with the beautiful sounds of a gong - And finally we share thoughts and questions, learning something new sometimes, generally supporting each other best we can at all times.

Note that we meet every Wednesday, 7:30 to 9 pm, and every Saturday, 2 to 3:30 pm on Midchester Ave. -- except for the first Saturday of the month, when we meet elsewhere and begin our meeting at 5 pm, followed by an informal potluck social starting about 7 pm.

(When you plan on staying for the potluck, see the log-in information posted at our monthly potluck page. That helps us get healthy, balanced meals.)

By the way, the meetup page may show only a few members planning to attend a particular meeting. That's because many people attend regularly and don't bother to RSVP for each meeting.  We never have only a few members at a meeting. Twenty members more usually attend each meeting.

Call Merrill or Mataji anytime you have questions:[masked]-5334.

results.description:
Basic Ground Rules for Participation

Please wear either a blue/black or white shirt to make things easy (Preferably bring both in case we need to mix the teams more evenly).


no need to respond at all if you can't/don't want to play

• if you do respond IN, please come unless something really urgent comes up (hangovers or better offers from your cooler friends not accepted for absences!)


• If you suck at Ultimate... you are more than welcome. This is open to ALL skill levels, ages etc. If you're really good, please pretend you suck every once in a while for the benefit of the rest of us! We're just here to run around and have fun. We all want to score and win but if you want to win at all costs, this is not the game for you.

• The trick with this group is making sure we have enough to play, so those who do show up don't waste a trip, so please make the effort this year to be honest with yourself and us about if you can/want to come down so we can make the right call for GAME ON or GAME OFF. If you are a "maybe" please indicate that via the comment section with a brief explanation (ie 80% chance I'll be there...). If you RSVP and are then unable to attend, please update your RSVP as soon as possible.

What is Ultimate Frisbee? In a nutshell <borrowed from Wiki> :

Ultimate is a limited-contact team field sport played with a disc (frisbee). Points are scored by passing the disc to a teammate in the opposing end zone. Other basic rules are that players must not take steps while holding the disc (maintain a pivot), and interceptions and incomplete passes are turnovers.

Closest analogy I could come up with = a mix of basketball and football, but played with a frisbee. You do not need to be an expert frisbee player/thrower etc. - it's all about having fun.

10v10, 75min+ game. Arrive early to warm up, and be ready to start at 2:00pm.


ALL players need to bring a white and black t-shirt and  ball.


It's a large field and some players may need the option to sub. If you're a dedicated goalkeeper let us know - Intermediate level.


****************************************************************

DETAILS:

• Played in a friendly environment. Pass the ball have fun.

• No rough tackles or play. Players are expected to bring a positive attitude, no screaming at/or berating team mates.

•  BRING A BALL. If you hit a ball into the river, you'll need to replace it!  If there aren't any dedicated goalkeepers playing, we rotate in goal every 5 mins.

• No metal cleats. Only turf or molded cleats.

• If you arrive late, pls wait until a break in the game. Inserting players in the middle of the game disrupts the flow, and it's not fair to those that arrive on time.


Payment goes toward field permit, equipment and fees.

See you at the pitch!


Note: The is a 2/3 regulation size field with full size goals. Not suitable for beginner level or inexperienced players.

By joining this group and attending events you agree to the Waiver Of Liability.

results.description:
**BUY SOMETHING TO SUPPORT THE VENUE** (this is nyc; don't expect us to be welcomed otherwise)

We will read article individually ahead of time and meet to discuss

"Putting the Altruism Back into Altruism: The Evolution of Empathy"

de Waal, Frans B.M. (01/2008). "Putting the Altruism Back into Altruism: The Evolution of Empathy". Annual Review of Psychology, 59 (1), p. 279.


Abstract

Evolutionary theory postulates that altruistic behavior evolved for the return-benefits it bears the performer. For return-benefits to play a motivational role, however, they need to be experienced by the organism. Motivational analyses should restrict themselves, therefore, to the altruistic impulse and its knowable consequences. Empathy is an ideal candidate mechanism to underlie so-called directed altruism, i.e., altruism in response to another's pain, need, or distress. Evidence is accumulating that this mechanism is phylogenetically ancient, probably as old as mammals and birds. Perception of the emotional state of another automatically activates shared representations causing a matching emotional state in the observer. With increasing cognition, state-matching evolved into more complex forms, including concern for the other and perspective-taking. Empathy-induced altruism derives its strength from the emotional stake it offers the self in the other's welfare. The dynamics of the empathy mechanism agree with predictions from kin selection and reciprocal altruism theory.

Article link: https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=Putting+the+altruism+back+into+altruism:+the+evolution+of+empathy&hl=en&as_sdt=0&as_vis=1&oi=scholart&sa=X&ved=0CBsQgQMwAGoVChMI-LmGuOiDyQIVhqA-Ch2KcgmO

results.description:
ABOUT THE PROGRAM The NYC Community Kayak Pool Program will begin at Riverbank State Park on Saturday, November 15, 2014 and runs through the beginning of March 7, 2015. The program provides basic kayak training to the public through the New York State Department of Parks in an Olympic size pool overlooking the Hudson River. These weekly classes are to introduce students to kayak equipment and learn basic strokes and safety. The program relies on instructors / volunteers from the kayak community.

Head Instructor Lee Reiser donates his time throughout the season. Lee is an ACA Level II Certified Instructor. He are assisted by individuals with a wide range of experience and certifications from the American Canoe Association and the British Canoe Union, two of themajor organizations for the sport of recreational kayaking.

Course 1 Saturdays November 14, 21,December 6,13


You must double click the link or go to:   NYC Community Kayak Program 2015- 2016 under the file section.

Registration is required by completing that information and returning it to:

Please send an email to Audrey Jackson. Program Coordinator [masked] orLee Reiser [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: By Car: From 138th Street head west and make a left onto 12th Avenue.
results.name: NYC Community Kayak Pool Program

group.name: Hudson River and Beyond  Kayaking Club

results.description:
This is my second year attending this valuable program. Under Lee Reiser, ACA level ll instructor, will help you hone your existing skills, learn new ones properly and introduce new people to the world of kayaking. In a beautiful heated pool with all kayaks and gear provided you can train for 2 hours learning bracing, rolling, rescues etc. and in return help the public for 2 hours by setting up and putting equipment away, greeting the public students, assisting instructors etc. All level of kayakers are welcome. The sessions are as follows:
Course 1 Saturday - Nov. 14, 21; Dec. 5, 12, 2015
Course 2 " - Jan. 9, 16, 23, 30, 2016
Course 3 " - Feb. 6, 13, 27; March 5, 2016


  The time for volunteers to practice is from 3 to 4 pm, and the time to volunteer is from 4 to 6 pm. Please arrive at least 15 minutes before so you can get ready. Pack a small bag with your change of clothes. The pool is heated but you may want to wear a wet suit, bringing your own PFD, paddle and skirt can add to your comfort level. Nose, ear plugs and goggles are helpful for rolling practice.  Pack a small bag with a change of clothes, towel etc. and bring a lock for the lockers.


Please fill out the volunteer packet which can be obtained from the Yonkers Club site: http://www.yprc.org
click on the Riverbank link once you are in the site and download the NY community Kayak Program packet. If you commit to at least 1 session you will be provided with a parking pass. If you are attending contact Audrey Jackson, Program Coordinator at:  [masked]

  DIRECTIONS-  From 138th St. head west and make a left onto 12th Ave., Take the 1st right beneath the West Side Hwy (by the restaurant) then swing right again past the first guard booth. Follow the roadway in and around, curve left and make a hard left U-turn into the parking area. Use the elevator to get to the park on the upper level walk to the pool area. Make sure you have a parking permit in your car window. Please car pool as parking is limited.

Riverbank State Park

Information For Volunteers

Fall 2015 I Winter 2016

New York Community Kayak Program

Fall 2015 I Winter 2016

ABOUT THE PROGRAM

The NYC Community Kayak Pool Program will begin at Riverbank State Park on Saturday, November 15, 2014 and

runs through the beginning of March 7, 2015. The program provides basic kayak training to the public through the

New York State Department of Parks in an Olympic size pool overlooking the Hudson River. These weekly

classes are to introduce students to kayak equipment and learn basic strokes and safety. The program relies on

instructors / volunteers from the kayak community.

Head Instructor Lee Reiser donates his time throughout the season. Lee is an ACA Level II

Certified Instructor. He are assisted by individuals with a wide range

of experience and certifications from the American Canoe Association and the British Canoe Union, two of the

major organizations for the sport of recreational kayaking.

PUBLIC KAYAK COURSES

Riverbank State Park promotes the program and

enrolls students in one of the six courses we hold. Each

course contains four classes. These weekly classes are

held on Saturdays from 4 to 6 pm. The curriculum will

cover basic skills using the ACA skill level I guidelines.

The age and experience level of the public students can

vary greatly. A student can be an adult or a child,

comfortable in the water or anxious about learning. We

break down into smaller groups so that each student gets

instruction tailored to their needs. This requires a lot of

volunteers and that's where you can help and learn at the

same time!

VOLUNTEERING

All kayakers are invited to volunteer, even beginners. Volunteers help out by setting up equipment, greeting the public

students, assisting Instructors and stowing gear at the end of each class.

In exchange for their service, volunteers are given training and pool time from 3 to 4 pm on Saturdays (prior to the

public classes). Volunteers may arrive at 2;45pm.You may practice your skills and learn new techniques from the

Instructors and other Volunteers, such as bracing, rolling, rescues and towing. For those interested in certification,

Lee Reiser will provide ACA Skills Level I & II training with an opportunity to receive ACA certification at the

completion of training. Certifications are held off site from the pool on a date, time, and place that will be announced.

We may also have a variety of guest speakers in the paddling community to better inform you of different groups to

paddle with and local options for paddling. These speakers and opportunities for networking in the paddling

community will be emailed by our Program Coordinator in brief messages.

Courses Dates

Course 1 Saturday November 14, 21,

December 5,12

Course 2 Saturday January 9, 16, 23, 30

Course 3 Saturday February 6, 13, 27

March 5

New York Community Kayak Program

Fall 2015 I Winter 2016

VOLUNTEER ELIGIBILITY

We are guests of Riverbank State Park and, as such, must adhere to their rules. There are also a few more

dictated by our insurance coverage. Please ...

• Sign/Check in at the front desk when you enter the Aquatic Center

• Sign into the waiver/attendance sheet at the start of each session.

• Read, sign, and agree to adhere to the Program Rules and Code of Conduct at the beginning of the season

• Follow instructions and orders from Pool personnel, Lifeguards as well as program staff

• Bring an adult with you to each class if you are under 18 years old, this person would need to sign the waiver/

attendance sheet for the participant that is not at least 18 years old.

.

GETTING TO RIVERBANK STATE PARK

The park overlooks the Hudson River on the west side of Manhattan. Located at 679 Riverside Drive, it spans

from 137th Street to 145th Street. For information call the park at (212)[masked] or via the web at

http://nysparks.state.ny.us/parks/93/details.aspx

The Aquatic Center is located on the west side of the football field overlooking the Hudson River. From the

traffic circle head toward the skating rink. Enter the main building, where you will immediately walk through

and exit on the other side; follow the pathway around the west side of the football field, towards the Hudson

River and the Aquatic Center.

Via Mass Transit: Take #1 train to 145th Street and walk west towards the Hudson River - after crossing

Riverside Drive you will see the main entrance to the park. Follow the pathway into the park and towards the football

field.

Optionally you may take the #1 train to 137th Street and proceed west towards the Hudson river after crossing

Riverside Drive follow the pathway to the large building on the west side of the track / football field.

The M11 bus in Manhattan, and the BX19 bus in the Bronx will take you directly to the park and drop you

off in the traffic circle adjacent to the skating rink.

By Car: From 138th Street head west and make a left onto 12th Avenue. Take the first right beneath the

West Side Highway (by the restaurant) then swing right again past the first guard booth. Follow the

roadway in and around, curve left then make a hard left u-turn into the parking area. Use the elevator or

stairs to get to the park on the upper level and proceed to the traffic circle.

From the West Side Highway: Take the 125th Street exit, make the first left past Fairway Supermarket and

double back on 12th Avenue. Take a left under the highway overpass (just before the restaurant) then swing

right past the first guard booth. Follow the roadway, curve left then make a hard left u-turn into the parking

area. Use the elevator or stairs to get to the park on the upper level and proceed to the traffic circle.

New York Community Kayak Program

Fall 2015 I Winter 2016

PARKING

The driving directions provided take you to the permit parking area. There are a limited number of spaces for

Instructors and Volunteers. If you plan to attend at least four classes we will provide you with a permit. Please

show the permit to the attendant and display it on your dashboard when at the park.

Under no circumstances are cars permitted to park outside of this area. Vehicles left at or near the traffic circle

may be ticketed and towed at the owner's expense. However, you may drop off and pick up passengers within

the traffic circle via the 145th Street entrance to the park.

WHAT WE PROVIDE

We will use decked kayaks of assorted sizes; most of these are whitewater and play boats, and river kayaks.

Space does not permit the use of full size sea kayaks. We also provide adult and child paddles, life vests and

spray skirts. A few pumps, paddle floats, tow lines and other rescue gear are available to practice rescues.

Optional: You may bring your own paddle, life vest and spray skirt provided they are washed in fresh water before

entering the pool. If you are interested in bringing in your own boat please check out the size of the pool first and

speak with one of the program staff to discuss this option.

WHAT TO BRING

Don't forget to bring a padlock so you can lock up your valuables and clothes.

Bring a towel, swimsuit and other approved water gear to wear in the pool, such as a wetsuit, water

shorts and rash guard. Non-approved clothing, such as T-shirts, cutoff jeans, and leotards, etc. is not

permitted in the pool.

Flip-flops or other footwear that has never been worn on the street may be worn around the pool area.

Street shoes are not permitted.

You may want to bring nose plugs, ear plugs and swim goggles for rolling practice. Masks the cover the nose, such

as snorkel or scuba masks, are NOT permitted. However a pair of goggles with a nose clip attached to the strap is

acceptable

WHEN YOU ARRIVE

• You may enter the Aquatic Center 15 minutes in advance of each day's class - please arrive no earlier than

2:40 pm on Saturdays.

• Sign in with the Attendant at the Aquatics Reception Desk. It’s a plain looking desk but sign in as an

Instructor / Volunteer. A list of participants will be printed so just sign next to your name. If your name is not

there fill your name at the bottom and it will add it for the following weeks.

• Proceed to the locker room to change and secure your belongings. Enter the pool area to assist in setting up

the boats and gear. You must also sign in the waiver/attendance sheet at the start on the pool side.

Essentially you sign in twice, once at the front desk and then a second time once you get pool side.

• All participants are supposed to shower prior to entering the pool, which is quite different from showing

before you enter the pool area.

New York Community Kayak Program

Fall 2015 I Winter 2016

OUR SPONSORS AND SUPPORTERS

Equipment and monetary support has been provided by numerous clubs and individuals. We thank our past sponsors

and look forward to their ongoing support - we can't do it without them! Please join us in recognizing their effort.

• Gowanus Dredgers Canoe Club & Owen Foote: for generously providing insurance last

season and sponsoring the program yet again this season

• Long Island City Community Boathouse and the Gowanus Dredgers: for the loan of paddles and

PFDs

• The Downtown Boathouse: for providing various small kayaks to be utilized in our program

• Andy Laiosa: for the use of various small kayaks suitable to our program;

• Jerry Blackstone and Lee Reiser: for the use of kayaks, skirts, pumps, paddle floats and other

miscellaneous equipment.

STILL HAVE QUESTIONS?

Please send an email to Audrey Jackson. Program Coordinator [masked] or

Lee Reiser [masked]

READY TO VOLUNTEER?

1. Print out and complete the forms: Volunteer Information, Program Rules (the

emergency info form is optional but recommended).

2. Bring your paperwork to your first class.

3. Email the program coordinator with any questions or concerns.

New York Community Kayak Program

Fall 2015 I Winter 2016

Volunteer Information (Complete one form for each Participant)

Name ________________________________ Email_____________________________________

ACA Membership # (if applicable)____________________________________________________

Describe your kayak experience _____________________________________________________

Please list your kayak certifications (none required) ______________________________________

Kayak Club Affiliations (if applicable) __________________________________________________

________________________________________________________________________________

________________________________________________________________________________

Do you have any specials goals or concerns? ___________________________________________

________________________________________________________________________________

________________________________________________________________________________

New York Community Kayak Program

Fall 2015 I Winter 2016

Program Rules & Code of Conduct (Complete one form for each Participant)

1. All Instructors and Volunteers must present their Program Identification Card and sign in at Aquatics Center

Reception.

2. Everyone must obey the Lifeguards and Pool Staff at all times and treat staff with courtesy and respect.

3. All Instructors and Volunteers agree to adhere to pool rules at all times, including but not limited to: no

walking or standing on the bulkhead, no diving, no running, no standing in boats, no paddle fights or rough play.

4. No bags are permitted on the pool deck; bring a lock and secure your belongings in the locker room.

5. Only aquatic apparel is permitted in the pool; cutoffs, t-shirts and other non-aquatic wear is not allowed.

Dear Volunteers

NOTICE TO ALL WHO ARE DRIVING BY CAR TO THE POOL FOR THE FIRST TIME

When you arrive, ask for a one day pass and THEIR instructions at the main gate at Riverside Dr. and 145th St. Follow the directions they will give you to get to the parking lot under the complex.

Turn around in the Circle. Then exit and follow THEIR printed instructions.

Park below complex. Leave pass on your dashboard. Take elevator and follow YOUR PRINTED VOLUNTEER PAMPHLET INSTRUCTIONS to get to the pool by walking across the grounds.

Then I will give a seasonal pass to those volunteers who commit to at least 3 dates.

Thank you.
results.name: Volunteer, practice, learn new kayaking skills at the NY Commnity Kayak Program!

Dharmachakra Buddhist Center (DBC) in the Millburn Village Mall, 2933 Vauxhall Road, Vauxhall, invites the public to a free Open House with a Public Talk and Guided Meditation from 3 to 4 p.m. on Saturday, Nov. 21.
Those who are new to meditation and Buddhism who would like to find out what it is all about are invited to attend.

Prepay here: 

https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=D4EP9WXT62RKL 

=============================================

The Upper East Side, just a swath of open land with ramshackle buildings before the Civil War, and later a middle class residential community of row houses and tenements, was by the turn of the 20th century already becoming the center of fine art and fine living it is today.  Come tour its unique gallery district, where hidden gems are often found upstairs and behind marked doors.

The tour will be led by Savona Bailey-McClain, founder and executive director of the West Harlem Art Fund, an organization that promotes art and culture in parks and other open spaces across NYC, as well as galleries. She has been involved in numerous public art installations and was recently selected to join TINA, a new international network for contemporary art curators based in Italy. 

IMPORTANT: 

- Prepay here:

results.description:
This month we'll discuss two articles sharing a common theme of public safety. First article is a Malcolm Gladwell piece about mass shootings and a new theory explaining how the epidemic spreads. The second article is a profile on Bill Bratton and the ongoing issues surround policing in New York City. It should an lively discussion covering guns, law enforcement and their impact.

Article #1:

Thresholds of Violence: How School Shootings Catch On. In the years since Columbine, school shootings changed; they became ritualized. Why? 


Article #2: 

Fixing Broken Windows

results.description:
Pewt. That was close. Pewt pewt. A few more lasers whiz past your head as your heart races with both excitement and fear, determined to come out of this alive. You find yourself running with your partner as you both manage to evade the onslaught of projectiles coming your way. 

Lub-dub. Lub-dub. You can feel your heart throbbing through your vest as you manage to take cover behind a nearby counter. How convenient.

You're trying to take it all in: the rush of adrenaline that's coursing through your veins, the cool beads of sweat trickling down your forehead and the incessant barking of nearby friends and foes. You close your eyes and breathe out a heavy sigh of relief. Phew. You've somehow manage to come out unscathed. 

You look over your shoulder to check in on your partner, the same one who's been with you since the beginning, the same one who's been fighting by your side. Tears begin to well up in your eyes. No... It can't be. You find your partner, Private Ryan, slumped over in a corner, back against the wall as he mouths for you to go on.

Your breath is ragged. Your jaw is clenched. Your eyes are watery as you fight to hold back those tears. You nod.

Welcome all to our third Social Saturday: Laser Tag edition! Come join us Recent College Grads (21-28) for an action-packed day of running, ducking and zapping as you'll not only meet new friends but get one helluva workout doing so.

Be it a professional laser tagger or an FNG, all skill levels are welcome! It's not about who can get the most points here as it is about who can have the most fun doing so. So don't be shy and jump into the fray. We're all about acceptance  :)

Event Location:

Bowlmor Chelsea Piers
Chelsea Piers - Pier 60
23rd Street & W. Side Highway
New York, NY 10011
Chelsea

Pricing:

General Admission: $11/person for 20 minutes
Bag Drop Offs/Lockers: Free (according to their front desk. There will be an open cubbyhole to store your belongings in.)

Nearby Train Stations:

- 23rd Street via C, E Train
- 34th Street - Hudson Yards via 7 Train

Where to Find Us:

We'll meet at the Stonefield on W 24th Street and the Hudson River to make sure we'll all be able to go in as a group. If you manage to get there before any of us, please, help yourself to a local stone and take a seat!

Contact Information:

If you have any questions and/or concerns, feel free to call/text Anthony at: (917) 526-3750.
results.name: [Chelsea Piers] PEWT. Laser Tag Adventures! (All levels welcome)

results.description:
This meeting is for genre fiction and creative fiction writers ONLY.

Genres covered are literary/upscale/art fiction, poetry, all kinds of mysteries, speculative fiction (fantasy, urban fantasy, horror and sci-fi), chick lit, women fiction, romance (all kinds, including historical, regent, sexy and erotica), western.

Short stories, flash fiction, novels, novellas and screenplays welcome. All ages.

Those of us who write fiction have special problems and requirements (such as creating scenes, inserting conflict in the story, word painting or character development).

Bring a piece to read and discuss, up to 1500 words, or simply bring yourself.

If you write non-fiction or memoire this is NOT the place for you. Please see the schedule for meetings of the non-fiction writers group or the Hudson Writers general meetings.

results.description:
10v10 teams, 75min+ game. Arrive early and be ready to go on time at 3:00pm - Intermediate level.

All players must bring a white and black t-shirt. Pass the ball & have fun!

****************************************************************

LOCATION:

Lower East Side, nr East River Park. 8-10 min walk from Delancey Street F train, head east along Houston, the field is south of Houston. Map here.

Details:

1) Teams divide into equal ability - players are welcome to signup with friends.

2) No metal cleats. Turf shoes / molded cleats only. Wear proper Soccer attire.

3) Played in a fun and chill environment. Rough play, tackles, or sliding are not tolerated.

4) If no dedicated goalkeepers, all players need to rotate in goal. Full size goals.

5) If you arrive late wait until a break in the game. Inserting players in the middle of the game disrupts the flow- it's not fair to those that arrive on time.


All players must RSVP and make payment before game time, this goes toward  field permits, equipment, meetup & CC fees.

CANCELLATIONS/REFUNDS:

You'll need to update your RSVP 24 hours before the match, to receive a credit for the next game. This is so other members have a chance to take your place.

See you pitch side!

Grand FC

By joining this group and attending events you agree to the Waiver Of Liability.

results.description:
Meet on the american football field (near the entrance close to the public restrooms)!!!

The game is scheduled to start at 3:00. We typically start 15 minutes after 3:00. Your RSVP is good if you come on time. If you come after teams are divided then you run the risk of not playing. Those who have RSVP’ed get first preference to play (This does not apply to anyone on the waiting list). Also, please  Un-RSVP if you will not be attending. That gives other people a chance to play.

Rules and guidelines:

These games are geared towards advanced to intermediate players.

Teams are divided by two team captains (captains pick players in turns in an attempt to keep teams balanced and competitive)

Physical play is allowed as long as it isn't overly aggressive or dirty.

Slide tackles are allowed only to block a shot on goal or to intercept a pass  NO slide tackling on a player with the ball.

Ball hogging is absolutely not tolerated

Keep in mind as we don't have permit, we need to be flexible.

results.description:
Over centuries of experience, breakthroughs, and setbacks, science has developed an approach that aims to eliminate the proliferation of error in thought. Viewed this way, the (quest for the) scientific method has been a driving force in shaping human history.Today we seem at crossroads. New information is bombarding us daily, demanding from each of us to take a stance in order to secure our future. Is climate change really threatening us? Are vaccines more harmful than good? Using knowledge gained from science, we will attempt to codify this set of cognitive skills so that everyone has the tools to address these important questions..

Niki Athanasiadou (PhD), is a research scientist in NYU. Her work focuses on the molecular mechanisms that regulate the timing and amplitude with which specific genes pass their instructions to the cell. She combines classical molecular biology techniques, high-throughput DNA sequencing technology, and computational approaches to build a comprehensive model of how these mechanisms are orchestrated. Niki writes for the on-line magazine BiteSize Bio on issues relating to the latest DNA sequencing technologies and the discoveries they have facilitated in the recent years. She was a guest on the podcast “Data Skeptic” discussing how personalized medicine and big data have revolutionized bio-medical research. Niki graduated from the School of Biology in Aristotele’s University of Thessaloniki (Greece), has a Master of Research, awarded with distinction by the University of York (UK) and received her PhD in Molecular and Cellular Biology from the University of Edinburgh (UK). Her work has been published in multiple scientific journals, and she has been awarded the Promega UK Young Scientist Award for Biochemistry, by the British Biochemical Society, alongside other fellowships and awards..

This event is free and open to the public.
results.name: Science Everyday: Simple Rules of Critical Thinking

results.description:
This meeting is for non-fiction and memoire writers.

Genres covered are all kids of non-fiction, autobiographies and memoires, academic non-fiction, news articles, blogs, etc.

Articles, book-size work and screenplays (for documentaries) welcome. All ages.

Those of us who write non-fiction have special problems and requirements (such as writing proposals, getting funding, checking sources, creating marketing platforms).

Bring a piece to read and discuss, up to 1500 words, or simply bring yourself. Please note that the non-fiction and fiction meeting of the Hudson Writers meetup group will be held in the same place at the same time. However, we will divide into two independent groups at two tables.
results.how_to_find_us: You can't miss us :)

results.description:
Prepay here: 

https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=WYM8MS9K65SRJ 

=============================================

The Upper East Side, just a swath of open land with ramshackle buildings before the Civil War, and later a middle class residential community of row houses and tenements, was by the turn of the 20th century already becoming the center of fine art and fine living it is today.  Come tour its unique gallery district, where hidden gems are often found upstairs and behind marked doors.

The tour will be led by Savona Bailey-McClain, founder and executive director of the West Harlem Art Fund, an organization that promotes art and culture in parks and other open spaces across NYC, as well as galleries. She has been involved in numerous public art installations and was recently selected to join TINA, a new international network for contemporary art curators based in Italy. 

IMPORTANT: 

- Prepay here: 

https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=WYM8MS9K65SRJ 

- If you tried to use the above link but had trouble with Paypal, an alternate payment link on Brown Paper Tickets will be emailed upon request. This will require an extra $1 charge to help cover the higher fees with this processor. 

- On November 20 (one day before), the price will go up to $25 if the event has not sold out.  Purchasing your spot as early as possible is recommended.

- RSVP without payment does NOT reserve your spot or lock in the price.

- Online payment deadline is 10:30am on the day of the tour.

- If space is available, payment can be made on-site ($25, cash only).

- Sorry, refunds and exchanges are not available (unless the event is cancelled).  However, if you are unable to attend, you can send someone in your place.  At check-in, simply have him or her mention the name under which you paid.

- If you are late or having trouble finding the group, call or text (917) 680-0656.  This is not a smartphone, so posting comments or sending messages through the Meetup site will NOT work.

- Please remember to bring photo ID in case it is requested by security at some of the galleries.

- Feel free to bring your camera.  Taking pictures is allowed.

- The tour will last approximately two hours.  Afterward, we will go somewhere nearby for food and socializing if there is interest.

- Art novices are welcome, as are people with extensive art backgrounds.

- This event is exclusively for members of my meetup groups and their guests, plus special invitees.  It is not open to the general public.


See you there! 

Milton & Savona
results.name: Upper East Side Art Gallery Tour (with Savona) - Only $16 Thru 11/19, $25 After

results.description:
Courtney aka @curlsandcouture and Fedorah aka @namedafterahat presents Project: Product Rescue!!


Product Rescue will be launching it's first event at the Mt. Olivet Baptist Church on 201 Lenox Ave on November 21, @ 1-5 p.m.  and they need your help in making this event a success. As the holiday season approaches let's make it a little more special for those in need by giving back to our communities.

How many of us have either brand new or lightly used products just sitting on shelves? Let's put them to good use! Come swap with other naturals or donate the unused products which we will be giving to 3 women's and children's shelters in NYC. We also ask that our curlfriends bring canned goods to donate to the shelters participating in the food drive.

Holiday meals will be available for purchase, giveaways and we have a great panel of naturals ready to answer all your hair care questions. A donation of 2 hair products and 3 canned goods is required for entry.

Please RSVP - - - space is limited. Let's give back together!!!

For tickets go to: www.projectproductrescue.eventbrite.com
results.how_to_find_us: www.projectproductrescue.eventbrite.com
results.name: Project: PRODUCT RESCUE (NOT AN NPC EVENT)

Rivington Music Rehearsal Studios 
188 Stanton Street, New York, NY 
Studio 4

Come join us for our music meetup. A gathering of musicians and singers of all levels, all types of music, amateur or professional in a studio space at Rivington Music Rehearsal Studios. The location can be mapped here. 

https://www.google.com/maps/place/Rivington+Music+Rehearsal+Studios/@40.7200783,-73.9833467,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m2!3m1!1s0x89c25981fb5b2301:0xb63fe55334c476fc 

Please note that in order to keep my expenses low for the meetup, I will begin to charge $8.00/person for the meetup. The fee will be collected at the rehearsal space. All overages over the costs of the meetup will be used towards future meetups to extend time and other future projects.

We will be working on a few songs which are listed below. We are open to requests, so please chime in with your RSVP on what you would like to play and we can accommodate. If you are having issues finding where to add this information in your RSVP. Please leave a message below and indicate what you like to work on.

More information on the studio and the the equipment included are here....

https://www.rivingtonmusic.com/studios/studio-4/#info

Since the Thanksgiving holiday is in two weeks and I am away the following weekend, We are having our next meetup next week. from 3:15 to 5:45PM on Saturday, November 21, 2015. Hope you can all make it. Date and time are subject to change. If you would like to suggest a different venue or day or time. Please let me know. We will see what we can do. 

The songs we will be working on are below. Sheet music, lyric sheets, and Chord Charts are all in a zip for each song and will be linked to the song shortly (if not already).

Pride (In The Name of Love) by U2

Naive by The Kooks

Little Red Corvette by Prince

I Wanna Be Sedated by The Ramones

Are You Gonna Be My Girl by Jet

Learn to Fly by Foo Fighters

You're A God by Vertical Horizon

Sex on Fire by Kings of Leon

If I Fell by The Beatles

Every Breath You Take by The Police

Looking forward to meeting you all!

results.description:
Join us for our annual Fall Fling!  Calling by Janine Smith and music by the Coffee Zombies!  Challlenging contras in the afternoon for experienced dancers who can do advanced moves without a walkthrough, followed by a dance for everyone that evening. Beginner's session will start at 7:30. 

ADMISSION
Challenging Contras: $15, $12 members & students {This dance is for  experienced dancers only; many dances will not be taught and you will be expected to know the basic and to be able to follow more complicated calls without a walkthrough}

Evening Dance: $20, $15 members & students 

Full Day: $28, $22 members & students 


Come dance to a live caller and band with Country Dance New York.  We are an intergenerational, multiethnic, smoke and alcohol free, inclusive community with one thing in common:  we love to contra and English country dance! 

Contra dance is a high energy American folk dance accompanied by live string music and taught by a caller.  No partner or experience required.  All dances are taught in advance and the figures are easy to learn.

Please bring a pair of clean, soft soled shoes {no spike heels} to dance in, and a water bottle.  We ask that you not use strongly scented grooming products as the smell can become overwhelming on the dance floor when things start to heat up. 

Country Dance New York has been hosting contra dances most Saturdays, and English country dancing most Tuesdays, at Church of the Village for almost 70 years.   COV is located at 201 W. 13 St., on the northwest corner of 7th Avenue.  

Beginners' session on Saturdays {for contra} is from 7:30 to 8:00.  Dancing for all from 8:00 until 10:45.  Hang out with us at a local diner after the dance.

Beginner's session on Tuesdays {for ECD} is from 7:00 to 7:30.  Dancing for all from 7:30 to 10:30.  

To see what contra dancing looks like, click here:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mM5vNzFxxBs 

To see what English country dancing looks like, click here:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rB40AvJnMUY 

Join us on Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/groups/2449906414/

For a complete schedule of our upcoming season, and for more information, visit our website.

See you on the dance floor!
results.how_to_find_us: Take the 1, 2, or 3 trains to 72nd Street.

results.description:
RSVP's start tonight at 10pm!   Please read below thoroughly!

New York, while we are not perfect, can serve as a model for the world in how we have for the most part been able to embrace a great variety of immigrant groups who have helped create a beautiful mosaic of people.  As a native New Yorker, I have also seen how so many different cultures have in turn embraced New York as a home.  It is a two-way street but it starts with compassion, tolerance and open-mindedness!

Purpose of this Meetup Experience: Get to know fellow groups members and learn about the history of NYC's Latin-American immigrants on this cultural and musical journey!  We'll enjoy two free concerts - first at El Museo del Barrio (free Admission) we'll enjoy some traditional New York style Latin Jazz featuring Bobby Sanabria and his band:

http://www.elmuseo.org/event/carnegie-concert-bobby-sanabria-ascension/

Free concert is from 4pm to 5pm inside El Museo.

Game Plan for Saturday: Meet in front of El Museo del Barrio at 5pm (after the 4pm concert inside).  Arrive early 3pm or whenever you  can to enjoy some of the exhibits (free admission).  http://www.elmuseo.org/onviewnow/


After a brief stroll through El Barrio (and if time a stop at an interesting local bookstore - and for a bite), we'll head to BAM in downtown Brooklyn by subway to enjoy the lively and eclectic sounds of Gato Loco.  Concert starts at 9pm but we should arrive by 8pm for seats.  IT may be a very popular gig and it is not a huge space!


http://www.bam.org/music/2015/gato-loco

BAM Cafe also serves food. We will try to eat in East Harlem though.

Feel free to just meetup at BAM Cafe, If you do that please do not RSVP, just meet the group there and post a message if you like - or surprise us :)

Directions here to BAM in Brooklyn:

http://www.bam.org/visit#/Peter-Jay-Sharp-Building/BAMcaf%C3%A9


My cell is[masked]-3005.  Feel free to text me when you arrive if you want to sit as a group for the 4pm concert at El Museo. Otherwise outside at 5th Avenue at 5pm in front of the museum.

Thanks for your cooperation!

Hank

results.description:
Let's explore the Met together every other Saturday with as little pressure as possible.

Go in the 81st entrance (not up the big stairs), and head straight back to the Uris Center for Education. We'll be at the set of benches with the number 8 above them inside the room. At 4:15pm we will split up.

We'll decide who will go see what with whom, wander galleries, and meet at the north entrance to the Balcony Bar at 5:30pm for cocktails, mocktails, and small plates to chat. We'll get tables at 5:40pm.

Everyone is responsible for their own admission and tab. I recommend you bring cash for your tab to make settling the check easier.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be at the set of benches with the number 8 above them inside the Center For Education room, which is straight ahead when you get past coat check. At 4:15pm we will split up. Then meet up at the north entrance to the Balcony Bar at 5:30.

results.description:
A recreational tap class for adults in a bar! 21+

4:00 pm Lesson I (perfect for beginners)

5:00 pm Lesson II (more advanced, tap shoes required)

$10 for one session, $17 for both!

$1 off all drinks at the bar. 
Please arrive 5-10 min before session to sign-in and get a drink.

If you have never tapped before or if it's been a while since you have, please come to Session I. This session introduces you to tap basics such as shuffles and flaps and then puts these skills into a fun, easy combination. (This can also be used as a warm-up for Session II). If you don't have tap shoes, please wear or bring closed-toe shoes such as sneakers.

If you own tap shoes and have at least a basic knowledge of tap fundamentals, you are welcome to attend Session II. This session moves faster than Session I and uses more advanced steps such as drawbacks and pullbacks in a fun, more advanced combination.

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to ask!

Dear Members:  I am Mr. Harrington's agent/rep. Mr. Harrington teaches privately coaching established actors and singers. For years his private rate has been $120/hr for this service. He started teaching through Meetup earlier this year and has as his goal to bring professional level instruction to the public at a rate that leaves no one behind. This demands tight scheduling of both his time and the room rental with Ripley-Grier Studios.For these reasons, I will be insisting to him that "no shows" be dropped from the group. The policy is this: If you RSVP you better show up. If you cancel you better do this by 4:00 pm the previous day.A word to the wise...Michael T. Harvey

results.description:
Welcome!

If you love to play basketball, but height is not your advantage, come out and play with people who aren't excessively tall! In the tradition of Spud Webb, anyone under 5'8", male or female, is welcome to join us on the court. We'll get some teams together and play some competitive, but relaxed bball-- and without any giant hands in our faces! :-p

We rent out the gym from 5:00-8:00pm. Please arrive at least 5-10 minutes early as the sooner everyone arrives, the sooner we can begin playing. Note that all games stop at 7:45pm as we must be out of the gym no later than 8:00pm. (If you get there late, please only ring the bell once. It is very loud! And it takes us a few minutes to get downstairs.) The gym is on the 10th fl. & has adjoining bathrooms, lockers, and water fountains.

Don't forget:


* You must be no more than 5'8" to play!

* You must RSVP on the site in order to attend!

* To be eligible to play we ask that you sign an annual waiver, which can be found here.


* If you have any problems with the prepay, just shoot one of the organizers a message. 

The Rules:

1. Play by ones and twos to 11 - win by one point.

2. Make it - take it.

3. Backcourt if the ball hits the rim or backboard. Air balls are fair game to put right back up.

4. Jump balls/disputed calls will be determined by a three pointer since the laws of basketball physics are very clear that "the ball never lies."

5. Walls, half-court line, and ceiling are out of bounds. 

6. Usually each team has 1-2 subs. Subs should enter mid-game (one of the teams reaches 6 points) and should start the following game. Teams can regulate themselves but let's just make sure everyone plays!

See you on the court! B-)

***SPECIAL NOTES***

Please do not show up unannounced (without RSVP):

This gym is small and 22 is the maximum number of players we can realistically allow. There is a waiting list if all spots have been taken. If you do show up unannounced we will have to ask you to leave. 

Refund Policy:

A refund/credit is available if you change your RSVP at least 24 hours in advance OR, if you change your RSVP within 24 hours, as long as you post a comment on the event page and someone picks up your spot (BOTH are required).

Lastly...

Feel free to bring your own basketball for shoot-around. And don't forget to clip your fingernails prior to game day. We tried playing with Edward Scissorhands once - it didn't turn out so well.

The Afterparty: 

We'll hit up McSwiggans (393 2nd Avenue @ 23rd St) later!
